author: T V
text:
Mothers with their newborn children rescued from thefire inside the Government General Hospital in Kalaburagion Wednesday.

Twenty-six newborns had a miraculous escape when a fire broke out at the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit of the Government General Hospital in Kalaburagi on Wednesday afternoon.

It was the presence of mind of two nurses and a lab attendant attached to the dental wing of the hospital which saved the day for the little ones. The trio — Fakirappa and M.P. Umesh and lab attendant Ramesh Pyati — were having lunch when two air-conditioners in the ICU caught fire.

They plunged into the smoke-engulfed area and broke the windowpanes to allow smoke to escape. They also arranged for the nursing and other staff members of the hospital to shift the newborns to other wards.

Fire tenders arrived at the scene and doused the fire in 30 minutes.

District Surgeon Nalini Namoshi said a short circuit was suspected to be the cause of the fire. She said eight air-conditioners in the ICU were replaced only two months ago, and the fire had damaged one completely.

Many state-of-the-art instruments, including emergency ventilators, suffered severe damage.

The rescued babies were shifted to private hospitals. Except for Mr. Fakirappa, who sustained injuries on the hands, no one involved in the rescue operations was injured.

Akkamahadevi Mudabi, great-grandmother of a newborn girl, said: “I have no words to explain my happiness that my great-granddaughter is safe… my granddaughter gave birth yesterday and the child was shifted to the ICU due to some health problems.”

Hospital staff helped to shift them from the neonatal ICU where 2 air conditioners caught fire
title: Miraculous escape for 26 newborns after fire in Kalaburagi govt. hospital
